When I try to run it, I get an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException error. Here is the code:public Date(String date) {    String dayz[];    dayz = date.split("/");    int m=Integer.parseInt(dayz[0]);    int d=Integer.parseInt(dayz[1]);    int y=Integer.parseInt(dayz[2]);    if(y<100) {         y=Integer.parseInt(dayz[2])+2000;    }    setComponents(m,d,y);}Here is the setComponents method: public void setComponents(int month, int day, int year) {    if (month < 1 || month > 12 || year < MIN_YEAR || day < 1 || day >     numDaysInMonth(month, year)) {        throw new IllegalArgumentException();    }    this.month = month;    this.day = day;    this.year = year;}Any help?
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.

Question: java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 2 error message: :I am writing some code trying to split a string (01/04/2010) into 3 different integers. When I try to run it, I get an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException error. Here is the code:public Date(String date) {    String dayz[];    dayz = date.split("/");    int m=Integer.parseInt(dayz[0]);    int d=Integer.parseInt(dayz[1]);    int y=Integer.parseInt(dayz[2]);    if(y<100) {         y=Integer.parseInt(dayz[2])+2000;    }    setComponents(m,d,y);}Here is the setComponents method: public void setComponents(int month, int day, int year) {    if (month < 1 || month > 12 || year < MIN_YEAR || day < 1 || day >     numDaysInMonth(month, year)) {        throw new IllegalArgumentException();    }    this.month = month;    this.day = day;    this.year = year;}Any help?
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer: The error is occurring because the string "01/04/2010" is not being split into 3 parts as expected. The split method in Java uses the regular expression "/" as the delimiter, which means it will split the string at every occurrence of "/". In this case, the string "01/04/2010" is split into ["01", "04", "2010"], which is why you're getting an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException error when you try to access dayz[2].

To fix this, you should use the "/" character as the delimiter in the split method. Here's how you can modify your code:

```java
public Date(String date) {
    String dayz[];
    dayz = date.split("/");
    int m = Integer.parseInt(dayz[0]);
    int d = Integer.parseInt(dayz[1]);
    int y = Integer.parseInt(dayz[2]);
    if (y < 100) {
        y = Integer.parseInt(dayz[2]) + 2000;
    }
    setComponents(m, d, y);
}
```

This code will correctly split the string "01/04/2010" into ["01", "04", "2010"], and then convert each part to an integer.

Alternatively, you can use the StringTokenizer class to split the string. Here's how you can modify your code using StringTokenizer:

```java
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

public Date(String date) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(date, "/");
    int m = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
    int d = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
    int y = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
    if (y < 100) {
        y = Integer.parseInt(dayz[2]) + 2000;
    }
    setComponents(m, d, y);
}
```

This code will also correctly split the string "01/04/2010" into ["01", "04", "2010"], and then convert each part to an integer.

Both of these solutions will prevent the ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException error from occurring.
<<<code>>>: $CODE
```java
public Date(String date) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(date, "/");
    int m = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
    int d = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
    int y = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
    if (y < 100) {
        y = Integer.parseInt(dayz[2]) + 2000;
    }
    setComponents(m, d, y);
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION
The code uses the StringTokenizer class to split the input string into three parts. The split is done using the "/" character as the delimiter. The StringTokenizer.nextToken() method is used to retrieve each part of the string. The parts are then converted to integers and used to call the setComponents() method to set the month, day, and year components of the Date object. If the year is less than 100, it is adjusted to be a 4-digit year by adding 2000 to it.
